calculation, residue theorem

Use the residue theorem to prove that

∫0∞ecos⁡xsin⁡(sin⁡x) dxx=π2(e−1).\int_0^\infty e^{\cos{x}} \sin\p{\sin{x}} \,\frac{\diff{x}}{x} = \frac{\pi}{2}\p{e - 1}.∫0∞​ecosxsin(sinx)xdx​=2π​(e−1).

Let f(z)=eeizzf\p{z} = \frac{e^{e^{iz}}}{z}f(z)=zeeiz​. Then if x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R,

f(x)=ecos⁡x+isin⁡xx=ecos⁡x(cos⁡(sin⁡x)+isin⁡(sin⁡x))x,f\p{x} = \frac{e^{\cos{x} + i\sin{x}}}{x} = \frac{e^{\cos{x}}\p{\cos\p{\sin{x}} + i\sin\p{\sin{x}}}}{x},f(x)=xecosx+isinx​=xecosx(cos(sinx)+isin(sinx))​,

so the imaginary part of f(x)f\p{x}f(x) gives us the original integrand. Observe that fff is holomorphic except with a pole at the origin. The residue of fff here is

Res⁡(f;0)=lim⁡z→0zf(z)=lim⁡z→0eeiz=e.\Res{f}{0} = \lim_{z\to0} zf\p{z} = \lim_{z\to0} e^{e^{iz}} = e.Res(f;0)=z→0lim​zf(z)=z→0lim​eeiz=e.

Observe also that if z=x+iyz = x + iyz=x+iy, then eiz=e−y(cos⁡x+isin⁡x)e^{iz} = e^{-y}\p{\cos{x} + i\sin{x}}eiz=e−y(cosx+isinx), so

∣eeiz∣=eRe⁡eiz=ee−ycos⁡x.\abs{e^{e^{iz}}} = e^{\Re{e^{iz}}} = e^{e^{-y}\cos{x}}.∣∣​eeiz∣∣​=eReeiz=ee−ycosx.

For 0<ε<R0 < \epsilon < R0<ε<R, consider the contour γε,R\gamma_{\epsilon,R}γε,R​ given by the segments [−R,−ε]\br{-R, -\epsilon}[−R,−ε] connected [ε,R]\br{\epsilon, R}[ε,R] by the two semi-circles {Reiθ∣0≤θ≤π}\set{Re^{i\theta} \mid 0 \leq \theta \leq \pi}{Reiθ∣0≤θ≤π} and {εeiθ∣π≤θ≤2π}\set{\epsilon e^{i\theta} \mid \pi \leq \theta \leq 2\pi}{εeiθ∣π≤θ≤2π} so that 000 is within the interior of γε,R\gamma_{\epsilon,R}γε,R​. On the top arc CRC_RCR​,

∣f(z)∣=ee−Rsin⁡θcos⁡(cos⁡θ)R≤eR≤e,\begin{aligned} \abs{f\p{z}} = \frac{e^{e^{-R\sin\theta}\cos\p{\cos\theta}}}{R} \leq \frac{e}{R} \leq e, \end{aligned}∣f(z)∣=Ree−Rsinθcos(cosθ)​≤Re​≤e,​

since sin⁡θ≥0\sin\theta \geq 0sinθ≥0. In other words, the integrals are uniformly bounded on a finite measure space, so by dominated convergence,

lim⁡R→∞∫CRf(z) dz=i∫0πlim⁡R→∞ee−iReiθ dθ=i∫0πe0 dθ=iπ.\lim_{R\to\infty} \int_{C_R} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} = i\int_0^\pi \lim_{R\to\infty} e^{e^{-iRe^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta = i\int_0^\pi e^0 \,\diff\theta = i\pi.R→∞lim​∫CR​​f(z)dz=i∫0π​R→∞lim​ee−iReiθdθ=i∫0π​e0dθ=iπ.

On the lower arc oriented clockwise, observe that because fff has a simple pole at z=0z = 0z=0, we get f(z)−ezf\p{z} - \frac{e}{z}f(z)−ze​ is holomorphic near 000. Hence,

∫Cεf(z) dz=∫Cε(f(z)−ez)+ez dz=∫Cε(f(z)−ez) dz+iπe→ε→0iπe,\begin{aligned} \int_{C_\epsilon} f\p{z} \,\diff{z} &= \int_{C_\epsilon} \p{f\p{z} - \frac{e}{z}} + \frac{e}{z} \,\diff{z} \\ &= \int_{C_\epsilon} \p{f\p{z} - \frac{e}{z}} \,\diff{z} + i\pi e \xrightarrow{\epsilon\to0} i\pi e, \end{aligned}∫Cε​​f(z)dz​=∫Cε​​(f(z)−ze​)+ze​dz=∫Cε​​(f(z)−ze​)dz+iπeε→0​iπe,​

since f(z)−ezf\p{z} - \frac{e}{z}f(z)−ze​ is bounded near 000. Hence, by the residue theorem and taking ε→0\epsilon \to 0ε→0, R→∞R \to \inftyR→∞, we get

iπ+iπe+∫−∞∞f(x) dx=2πie  ⟹  ∫0∞ecos⁡xsin⁡(sin⁡x) dxx=π2(e−1),i\pi + i\pi e + \int_{-\infty}^\infty f\p{x} \,\diff{x} = 2\pi i e \implies \int_0^\infty e^{\cos{x}}\sin\p{\sin{x}} \,\frac{\diff{x}}{x} = \frac{\pi}{2}\p{e - 1},iπ+iπe+∫−∞∞​f(x)dx=2πie⟹∫0∞​ecosxsin(sinx)xdx​=2π​(e−1),

since the integrand is even, and by taking imaginary parts.

Solution.
